factoid: Natásha said Natásha will never again be as happy and tranquil as Natásha is now.
Nicholas heard Natásha's spontaneous, happy, ringing laughter.
Natásha thought how well Anísya carried herself.
Natásha said there are still lights in the drawing room.
Natásha pointed to the windows of the house that gleamed invitingly in the moist velvety darkness of the night.
Count Ilyá Rostóv resigned the position of Marshal of the Nobility because the position of Marshal of the Nobility involved too much expense.
Count Ilyá Rostóv and Countess Ilyá Rostóv often conferring anxiously and privately.
Count Ilyá Rostóv and Countess Ilyá Rostóv heard suggestions to sell the fine ancestral Rostóv house and estate near Moscow.
The life at Otrádnoe was quieter than in former years.
The enormous house and its lodges were full of people and more than twenty sat down to table every day.
Dimmler the musician lived in the house.
Dimmler the musician had a wife who lived in the house.
Vogel the dancing master lived in the house.
Vogel the dancing master had a family who lived in the house.
Belóva, an old maiden lady, lived in the house.
Pétya’s tutors lived in the house.
The girls’ former governess lived in the house.
Other people who found it preferable to live in the count’s house lived there.
The house had more than twenty people who sat down to table every day.
The house had many people who settled down in the house almost as members of the family.
The house had many people who were obliged to live in the count’s house.
The house had many people who simply found it preferable and more advantageous to live in the count’s house than at home.
The house had many people who were invited to live there.
The house had many people who were tutors.
The house had many people who were governess.
The house had not as many visitors as before, but old habits remained unchanged.
Nicholas had even enlarged the hunting establishment.
There were still fifty horses in the stables.
There were still fifteen grooms in the stables.
There were expensive presents and dinner parties to the whole district on name days.
The count played games of whist and boston.
During the games of whist and boston the count let himself be plundered of hundreds of rubles every day by his neighbors.
The neighbors looked upon an opportunity to play a rubber with Count Ilyá Rostóv as a most profitable source of income.
The count moved in his affairs as in a huge net.
The count tried not to believe he was entangled but became more and more so at every step.
The count felt too feeble to break the meshes or to set to work carefully and patiently to disentangle them.
The countess with her loving heart felt that her children were being ruined.
The countess felt that it was not the count’s fault for he could not help being what he was.
The countess felt that he suffered from the consciousness of his own and his children’s ruin.
The countess tried to find means of remedying the position.
From her feminine point of view the only solution was for Nicholas to marry a rich heiress.
The countess felt this to be their last hope.
If Nicholas refused the match the countess had found for him, she would have to abandon the hope of ever getting matters right.
The match was with Julie Karágina, daughter of excellent and virtuous parents.
Julie Karágina was a girl the Rostóvs had known from childhood.
Julie Karágina became a wealthy heiress through the death of the last of her brothers.
The countess wrote directly to Julie’s mother in Moscow suggesting a marriage between their children.
The countess received a favorable answer from Julie’s mother.
Julie Karágina replied that she was agreeable, and everything depended on her daughter’s inclination.
Julie Karágina invited Nicholas to come to Moscow.
The countess, with tears in her eyes, told her son that now both her daughters were settled, her only wish was to see him married.
The countess said she could lie down in her grave peacefully if that were accomplished.
The countess told him that she knew of a splendid girl and tried to discover what he thought about marriage.
Nicholas thought how charming Natásha of mine is.
Nicholas thought he had no other friend like Natásha.
Nicholas thought they might always drive about together.
Natásha thought Nicholas was a darling.
Natásha said she would never again be as happy and tranquil as she is now.
